text: I got an IUD this week. Yeah. I am not seeing anybody right now, but you know what they say, dress for the job you want, right? Not the job you have.

feedback.summary: Great punchline via misdirection — add a smoother lead-in

details.message: Consider adding a short sentence that acknowledges the irony of getting an IUD while single, to make the punchline misdirection feel smoother.
The punchline lands well — you could add a quick, subtle tag like 'CEO of disappointment' to escalate the humor.

text: Yeah, I'm single, if you can believe it. And being single, it has changed my priorities in a way that I'm not super proud of. Okay, I'll give you an example.

feedback.summary: Good setup — add a clearer tone shift to heighten curiosity

details.message: The transition into 'changed my priorities' is a bit flat — consider punching it up with something more specific or odd to spike curiosity.
You could tag the 'if you can believe it' line with an absurd reason why someone *shouldn’t* believe you're single.

text: We all remember two years ago, the racial uprising, right?... Feels like I'm not asking for too much, you know what I mean?

feedback.summary: Strong juxtaposition of seriousness and personal shallowness — refine pacing

details.message: The contrast between the intense protest and the romantic observation is funny — consider inserting a short pause or sentence between the two ideas to let the turn breathe.
Clarify your own role earlier in the story — e.g., 'I was there, marching' — to keep focus on you before pivoting to the guy’s gesture.

text: Yeah, yeah, it's tough being single... That just wasn't true.

feedback.summary: Good personal contrast — build the reveal with a sharper punch

details.message: The image of removing a bandaid is funny but low-energy — consider exaggerating the fear for comedic effect ('I had to call my therapist').
The ‘kinkiest girl’ line would land harder if you explicitly contrast it with your real activity *before* delivering it — building tension first.

text: I've been trying to mix things up... It's fucking tough.

feedback.summary: Strong metaphor — add a sharper ending line

details.message: The MLM metaphor is excellent — you could extend it by comparing your dating pitch to product features: 'low maintenance, emotionally available… limited edition.'
The final line 'you cannot girl boss your way...' is great — you might follow it with a sharper tag like 'Turns out his heart is not a startup.'

text: It was a holiday weekend... Anyway.

feedback.summary: Dark but effective punchline — consider softening setup tone

details.message: This segment relies on dark humor — to keep audience with you, consider using a lighter tone leading into the urn line before dropping it.
The ‘cremation burns fat’ line is strong — you might tag it with a faux-inspirational line like 'Hot girl summer just got literal.'

text: Yeah, I do have some body image issues... Okay.

feedback.summary: Smart turn on 'revenge body' idea — reinforce payoff

details.message: The 'revenge personality' twist is clever — consider giving an absurd example of what that might look like before launching into the next segment.
This could be a nice callback setup if later you reference personality traits as revenge tools again.

text: My revenge personality, I'm thinking, is just gonna be a really cool British girl... Pretty freaking rock and roll. Yeah, yeah.

feedback.summary: Fun character shift — consider variety in phrasing

details.message: The British persona is a funny contrast — maybe add one line showing how poorly you actually do the accent or stay in character.
‘Rock and roll’ is repeated a lot — you could swap one of them for a synonym or visual metaphor to keep it fresh.

text: I want to talk to you guys about something that's important to me... you need to calm down.

feedback.summary: Smart cultural commentary — tighten setup for stronger rhythm

details.message: The segment is long — consider trimming some historical comparisons (e.g., 'some women' line) to maintain pacing.
The 'Gen Z voting skepticism' premise is strong — clarify upfront why you're making the comparison to fashion/culture for a tighter argument.
The 'trailer for Avatar 2' timeline is great — you could add a tag like 'James Cameron could never move that fast.'
